model_input:
[Task Description]
You will be given DIALOGUE CONTEXT and MEMORY.
Your job is to judge if MEMORY contains helpful past information for a language model, representing Unknown, to generate a proper next response based on DIALOGUE CONTEXT.

If the DIALOUGE CONTEXT does not require the model to utilize past information for response generation, say "N/A".
Say "Yes" if MEMORY contains such helpful information and say "No" if it dose not.
Provide a brief explanation for your judgement.

[Format Regulation]
Generate your output below OUTPUT using the following format:
Brief explanation: your explanation
Judgement: "Yes", "No", or "N/A"

[Task]
DIALOGUE CONTEXT:
Mentor, I'm feeling really lonely in this new city. I don't know anyone yet and I miss my old friends.
I understand that starting over can be tough, Mentee. But remember, this is also an opportunity for you to meet new people and make new connections.
Yes, I know, but it's easier said than done. I feel like everyone already has their own group of friends here.
That's just a fear, Mentee. You can join clubs or organizations that interest you to meet like-minded people. You could also start volunteering around the city to meet new people.
Those are good suggestions, Mentor. I'll consider joining a club or volunteering.
And remember, it's also important to keep in touch with your old friends. You can schedule video calls or even plan a visit back home.
That's true, I'll make sure to keep in touch. Thanks for the advice, Mentor.
Anytime, Mentee. Is there anything else you want to talk about or any updates you'd like to share?
Actually, I did make a new friend at work. We've been hanging out after work sometimes and it's been nice.

[MEMORY]
Related Evidences: (1) {'Related Topics': 'Job decision', 'Related Summaries': 'Mentee informs Mentor about deciding to take a job in the city and discusses the reasons behind the choice.', 'Related Dialogues': '### Mentee: Mentor, I finally made a decision about the job. ### Mentor: Great to hear! What did you decide? ### Mentee: I decided to take the job in the city. I know it was a tough choice, but I feel confident that it's the right decision for me. ### Mentor: That's wonderful, Mentee. Can you share more about why you came to that decision? ### Mentee: Well, I weighed all the pros and cons of each option and ultimately decided that the opportunities in the city were too good to pass up. Plus, I think it'll be a great chance for me to grow both personally and professionally. ### Mentor: That's a very mature way of looking at things, Mentee. You're making a thoughtful and well-informed decision. ### Mentee: Thank you, Mentor. I feel a lot more at peace now that I've made up my mind. ### Mentor: I'm glad to hear that. You know, I think this is a great reflection of the work that you've done in advocating for women and girls. You're showing that it's possible to make difficult decisions that are in line with what you believe is best for yourself and others. ### Mentee: That's really kind of you to say, Mentor. It's true that my work has taught me a lot about the importance of standing up for what you believe in and making choices that align with your values. ### Mentor: Absolutely. And I have no doubt that your dedication to these principles will serve you well in this new job. You should be very proud of yourself, Mentee.' }(2) {'Related Topics': 'College application stress', 'Related Summaries': 'Mentee shares feeling overwhelmed with the college application process, and Mentor provides reassurance and study tips.', 'Related Dialogues': '### Mentee: Mentor, I'm feeling really overwhelmed with the college application process. It seems like there's always one more thing I need to do or study for. ### Mentor: It's understandable that you're feeling overwhelmed, Mentee. Applying to colleges can be a stressful experience. But remember, you're not alone in this. Many students are feeling the same way. ### Mentee: I know, but it feels like everyone else has everything together. They have their applications submitted and their essays already written. ### Mentor: Don't compare yourself to others, Mentee. Everyone works at their own pace. What matters is that you're putting in the effort and taking the steps necessary to reach your goals. ### Mentee: That's true. But I feel like I'm running out of time. The SAT is next month and I don't feel ready. ### Mentor: Have you been studying consistently? ### Mentee: Yes, but it feels like there's so much material to cover. ### Mentor: Remember to break it down into manageable chunks. Schedule study sessions and breaks to prevent burnout. And don't forget to utilize resources like practice exams and review books. ### Mentee: Thanks, Mentor. I appreciate your advice. ### Mentor: Of course, Mentee. And always remember to take care of yourself. A healthy mind and body will help you tackle any challenge that comes your way.' }
```
